column1: #Text=World Wildlife Fund : 75 % of seafood species consumed in Singapore not caught sustainably
#Text=The Singaporean branch of the World Wildlife Fund ( WWF ) published a guide yesterday critiquing the practices employed to catch seafood destined for sale in the country .

#Text=According to the publication , three-quarters of the more than 40 species of seafood commonly consumed by Singaporean residents were obtained in a manner detrimental to environmental sustainability .

#Text=The guide , titled the Singapore Seafood Guide , lists fish species such as Indian threadfin , silver pomfret , and yellowbanded scad , all frequently used in Singaporean dishes , under its " Avoid " category .

#Text=Highlighting the high rates at which these species are being fished and consumed , the WWF said , " Without collective and decisive action , these popular fish could disappear from Singapore 's menus within our lifetime . "

#Text=On her organization 's reasons for publishing the guide , WWF-Singapore CEO Elaine Tan stated , " We are squandering one of our greatest natural resources by failing to manage our fish stocks sensibly .
